raw_text:
Castaignede fires Laporte warning
 
 Former France fly-half Thomas Castaignede has warned the pressure is mounting on coach Bernard Laporte following their defeat by Wales.
 
 France suffered a shock loss against the Welsh at the weekend after looking on course for an easy win. Castaignede told BBC Sport: "The pressure is big on Laporte after a huge loss to New Zealand, a slim win over Scotland and a miracle against England. "But the French have to get behind him and the team at Lansdowne Road." Following victories over South Africa and Australia in November, France were deemed by many to be the world's leading side. But they were then trounced 45-6 by New Zealand and only just beat Scotland after the Scots had a try disallowed in their Six Nations opener. It then took some woeful spot kicking from Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley to help them to victory against England at Twickenham. <
 
 Castaignede said: "You can't say any of those results have eased the pressure on Laporte. "Had England's kickers not been so bad, the position in the Six Nations would be very different now." Laporte has been criticised for France's negative tactics in their wins over Scotland and England. But his side played a more free-flowing style against Wales, making a mockery of the opposition's defence in the first half before suffering a shock turnaround in fortunes after the interval. "All the chat in France has been about how France will play against Ireland," said Castaignede ahead of the 12 March tie. "Everyone wants to see the sort of play we saw against Wales. But everyone also wants a win." Castaignede, a veteran of 43 international caps, admitted the French would go in as underdogs against Ireland.
 
 "Going to Ireland is never easy but the way they're playing right now, it's harder than ever," said Castaignede. "They're very experienced and don't often lose at home. They've got some great forwards and some electric runners on the break." Despite praising the Irish he claimed the Welsh had the upper hand in the Six Nations run-in. "Ireland have such a good pack but Wales are something else on the break," he added. "At the weekend they were simply awesome. As a Frenchman it was disappointing to see, but you had to admire it. "Their commitment to every cause can make them win this championship." The 30-year-old also tipped Yann Delaigue to start ahead of Frederic Michalak at number 10 after an impressive display in Paris last weekend. "Delaigue played really well and admittedly Michalak played well too," said Castaignede. "I'm just glad I'm not the one who has to make the decision."
llama3.2:1b: Thomas Castaigne warns that pressure is mounting on coach Bernard Laporte following France's defeat by Wales, despite their recent wins over New Zealand, Scotland, and England.
Castaigne praises Ireland but notes they are "never easy" opponents due to their experience and strong forwards.
He also tips Yann Delaigue to start ahead of Frederic Michalak at number 10 after a good performance in Paris last weekend.
llama3.2:3b: Thomas Castaigne warns of mounting pressure on coach Bernard Laporte following France's shock loss to Wales, citing recent tough results against New Zealand, Scotland, and England, with Castaigne praising Wales' break-through play and tipping Yann Delaigue for starting spot at number 10.
gemma2:2b: Thomas Castaignede believes there is significant pressure on coach Bernard Laporte following France's recent defeats in the Six Nations.
He acknowledges that while some results have improved French spirits, the team still faces a difficult challenge against Ireland.
Despite acknowledging Ireland's strength, he argues that Wales possesses an advantage during their current form in the run-up to the championship.
Castaignede also predicts Yann Delaigue's potential starting position at fly-half after his impressive performance last weekend.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A French fly-half named Thomas Castaignede is warning that the pressure on coach Bernard Laporte is growing due to a disappointing loss against Wales in the Six Nations.
He believes New Zealand, Scotland, and England are all contenders for the championship while the Welsh team is underperforming, citing concerns about their tactics and defense.
Castaignede also expresses hope for Ireland's victory over Wales in the next game after their win over England at Twickenham.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Thomas Castaignede warns Bernard Laporte under pressure following France's loss to Wales, criticizing his tactics.
Castaignede criticizes French coach Laporte for his handling of recent matches and suggests Ireland poses a stronger challenge than previously expected.
He predicts tough conditions against Ireland but still believes France will play well against them based on their performances in the Six Nations earlier this season.
qwen2.5:3b: Thomas Castaignede, former France fly-half, warns coach Bernard Laporte under pressure after France's defeat by Wales in the Six Nations.
Despite recent victories over South Africa and Australia, France suffered heavy losses against New Zealand (45-6) and narrowly beat Scotland (19-16).
Laporte faces criticism for his team's tactics but praised their performance against Wales.
Castaignede predicts a tough match against Ireland, who he considers as experienced and strong defensively.
He tipped Yann Delaigue to start at number 10 ahead of Frederic Michalak.
opencoder:1.5b: Castaignede fires Laporte warning.
Former France fly-half Thomas Castaignede has warned the pressure is mounting on coach Bernard Laporte following their defeat by Wales.
France suffered a shock loss against the Welsh at the weekend after looking on course for an easy win.
Castaignede told BBC Sport: "The pressure is big on Laporte after a huge loss to New Zealand, a slim win over Scotland and a miracle against England."
Following victories over South Africa and Australia in November, France were deemed by many to be the world's leading side.
But they were then trounced 45-6 by New Zealand and only just beat Scotland after the Scots had a try disallowed in their Six Nations opener.
It then took some woeful spot kicking from Charlie Hodgson and Olly Barkley to help them to victory against England at Twickenham.
Castaignede said: "You can't say any of those results have eased the pressure on Laporte.
"Had England's kickers not been so bad, the position in the Six Nations would be very different now."
Laporte has been criticised for France's negative tactics in their wins over Scotland and England.
But his side played a more free-flowing style against Wales, making a mockery of the opposition's defence in the first half before suffering a shock turnaround in fortunes after the interval.
"All the chat in France has been about how France will play against Ireland," said Castaignede ahead of the 12 March tie.
"Everyone wants to see the sort of play we saw against Wales.
But everyone also wants a win."
Castaignede, a veteran of 43 international caps, admitted the French would go in as underdogs against Ireland.
Despite praising the Irish he claimed the Welsh had the upper hand in the Six Nations run-in.
"Ireland have such a good pack but Wales are something else on the break," he added.
"At the weekend they were simply awesome.
As a Frenchman it was disappointing to see, but you had to admire it.
"Their commitment to every cause can make them win this championship."
The 30-year-old also tipped Yann Delaigue to start ahead of Frederic Michalak at number 10 after an impressive display in Paris last weekend.
"Delaigue played really well and admittedly Michalak played well too," said Castaignede.
"I'm just glad I'm not the one who has to make the decision.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The French rugby team has warned their coach Bernard Laporte that the pressure is mounting on him after a tough loss to Wales at home.

The French suffered a shock defeat against the Welsh, including victories over South Africa and Australia but being trushed 45-6 by New Zealand, only barely winning Scotland after disallowing a try in their Six Nations opener.
Castaignede highlighted that England's kickers were not performing well, implying the Six Nations position might be more varied now.
Laporte criticized France for using negative tactics against Scotland and England but praised their free-flowing style against Wales, showing difficulty getting back on track.
Castaignede also hinted at Yann Delaigue starting ahead of Frederic Michalak for a potential match with Wales later this week.
tinyllama:1.1b: The French rugby team, after losing against Wales, faces a huge pressure due to their negative tactics in their wins over Scotland and England, but they are underdogs against Ireland.
Ex-France fly-half Thomas Castaignede warns that the pressure is mounting on coach Bernard Laporte following France's losses against New Zealand and Australia.
In contrast, Castaignede praises Ireland's attackers and says it will be tough to beat them in the upcoming Six Nations run-in.
Castaignede also mentions Yann Delaigue as his preferred starter ahead of Frederic Michalak at number 10, citing his impressive performance against Paris last weekend.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The message from the AI assistant is: "The French team has been under a lot of pressure after losing to Wales in their recent matches, but former France fly-half Thomas Castaignede warns that the pressure is on coach Bernard Laporte.
He suggests that the French can't afford to let the pressure get to them and they should focus on playing good football."
phi:2.7b: Former France fly-half Thomas Castaignede warned coach Bernard Laporte that pressure is mounting after their defeat by Wales in the Six Nations, citing tough losses against New Zealand and a slim win over Scotland.
French players have been criticized for negative tactics in previous games, but their win against England has helped to elevate their position as the world's leading team.
Castaignede acknowledged the difficulty of facing Ireland, who are experienced at playing at home, but praised their rivals' performance on the break.
He also suggested Delaigue should start ahead of Michalak for the 12 March game against Ireland.
orca-mini:3b: Thomas Castaignede has warned that the pressure is mounting on Bernard Laporte following France's defeat by Wales, but he also praised Ireland's ability to break and suggested that Wales had an upper hand in the Six Nations run-in.
Castaignede said that the French would go into the Ireland game as underdogs but praised their opponents' commitment and potential to win the championship.
hermes3:3b: Castaigne warns Laporte of growing pressure after France's losses.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Former France fly-half, Thomas Castaignede, warned that coach Bernard Laporte is under increasing pressure following France's shock loss to Wales.

Despite victories over South Africa and Australia in November, France was previously deemed the world's leading side, but they suffered a 45-6 defeat by New Zealand and only just beat Scotland after controversy surrounding their negative tactics.
Castaignede suggested that had England's kickers been better, the position in the Six Nations would be different now.
He also praised Ireland's chances against France, calling them "very experienced" and saying Wales had the upper hand in the run-up to the championship.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Former France fly-half Thomas Castaignede warned that pressure is mounting on coach Bernard Laporte after France's shock defeat to Wales, following a heavy loss to New Zealand, a narrow win over Scotland, and a fortunate victory against England.
Despite earlier wins over South Africa and Australia, France's inconsistent performances have raised concerns.
Laporte has been criticized for negative tactics, though France played a more attacking style against Wales before collapsing in the second half.
Castaignede acknowledged France as underdogs against Ireland, praising their experience and strong forwards, while also highlighting Wales' attacking prowess as a major threat in the Six Nations.
He suggested Yann Delaigue could start over Frederic Michalak at fly-half after an impressive performance.
stablelm2:1.6b: Thomas Castaignede warns that pressure is mounting on France coach Bernard Laporte following their defeat by Wales.

Despite wins over South Africa and Australia earlier in the year, France lost to New Zealand and narrowly beat Scotland before ultimately needing spot kicking against England to secure a victory at Twickenham.
Castaignede admits France will be underdogs against Ireland, praising the Irish team's experience and strong pack.
He predicts that Wales' impressive performance against France can give them an upper hand in the upcoming Six Nations match.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Former France fly-half Thomas Castaignede warns that head coach Bernard Laporte is under immense pressure following their surprising 45-13 defeat by Wales in the Six Nations.
This loss follows previous close matches against New Zealand (who they outscored narrowly) and England, both of which could have been losses had not for crucial kicks.
Castaignede emphasizes that France's reputation as a top side has significantly diminished due to these results.
He expects the French team to play more expansive rugby against Ireland on March 12, aiming to replicate their performance against Wales.
However, he acknowledges Ireland's strong home form and dominant pack.
Castaignede predicts Yann Delaigue will start over Frederic Michalak at fly-half, citing Delaigue's impressive showing in Paris.
Despite the pressure on Laporte, Castaignede believes Ireland, with their committed players and potential to win the championship, could emerge victorious.
